awd_titl_txt: Doctoral dissertation research:   Research on Xong (ISO 639-3 code mmr), a Miao-Yao Language of Hunan Province, China
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this dissertation project are twofold. First, it will produce a descriptive grammar -- that is, a comprehensive, book-length phonological and grammatical description -- of the Xong language, spoken by nearly a million people in China's Hunan and Guizhou Provinces. Second, it will allow the collection of several hundred hours' worth of recorded Xong sentences, folktales, conversations, and other texts. All necessary data will be collected in Xong-speaking villages in western Hunan, and both grammar and recordings will be made freely available to the public upon the project's completion.

Although Xong has received some linguistic influence from Mandarin and other Chinese languages over the past several centuries, it is completely unrelated to them. Instead, it belongs to the Miao-Yao family, meaning that it is in fact distantly related to the Hmong language spoken in many parts of Southeast Asia and the US. The Miao-Yao family has been estimated to contain over a hundred mutually unintelligible languages, but it remains one of the least described language families in the world. Xong itself is a perfect example, as the language has been almost completely ignored in the English linguistic literature.
This lack of research would be unfortunate for any Miao-Yao language, but it is particularly so in the case of Xong. The language has a number of unusual features, including nearly seventy distinct consonants (in contrast, English and Mandarin each have around two dozen) and eight distinct tones (Mandarin has only four, and Cantonese and Vietnamese each have only six). Xong displays several interesting grammatical features as well, including unusually rich systems of nominal prefixes, relative clauses, and ideophones.

This project will not only produce the most comprehensive linguistic description of Xong to date, but indeed the most comprehensive description of any Miao-Yao language. Furthermore, it will be able to serve as a model for similar descriptions of China's other understudied languages in the future.  This award will also enhance the training of a graduate student.

The primary outcome of this project was the completion of a comprehensive description (i.e. a "grammar") of Xong, a language spoken by approximately 900,000 people in the provinces of Hunan and Guizhou in south-central China. In producing this description, the author primarily relied on the fieldwork data he collected over a period of ten months in Xong-speaking villages in the mountains of western Hunan. The resulting work provides full analysis and discussion of both the language's sound system and its grammatical system, and, incidentally, it also served as the author's doctoral dissertation.

In particular, the first four chapters of the description cover a number of non-grammatical topics, including (but not limited to) a review of previous studies of Xong, a description of the author's fieldwork site and research methodology, and a thorough analysis of the Xong sound system. The next four chapters discuss various aspects of Xong's remarkably complex noun phrases, while the last four chapters examine Xong clauses, verbs, and other related issues. Finally, two annotated Xong texts - one a traditional folktale, the other a naturalistic conversation - are included as appendices, with each one being accompanied by an English translation.

While a grammar of any understudied language would naturally help advance the field of linguistics and humanity's understanding of language in general, there are several reasons why Xong is particularly deserving of description and analysis. First, Xong possesses a number of unusual linguistic features, including a very large number of consonants (65, compared to 24 in English and 25 in Mandarin), a large number of tones (8, compared to 6 in Cantonese and Vietnamese, 4 in Mandarin, and none in English), and a highly complex system of relative clause constructions compared to most other languages spoken in China (these constructions are roughly equivalent to English ones like the man who saw me or the dog that ran away).

Second, despite the fact that virtually all Xong speakers live in China, the Xong language is entirely unrelated to any Chinese language, including Mandarin and Cantonese. It belongs instead to the Miao-Yao (or Hmong-Mien) language family, a group of some hundred-plus distinct languages which are spoken in many isolated mountain communities across southern China. (Some Miao-Yao languages are also spoken in certain mainland Southeast Asian countries and even certain Western countries, the most well known of which in the U.S. is almost certainly the Hmong language.) Regrettably, despite its large size and fascinating member languages, relatively little work has been performed on the Miao-Yao family by Western scholars. In fact, to the best of the author's knowledge, the grammar he produced in the course of this project is the first full-length grammar of any Miao language to be published in English, and it will thus hopefully serve as a model for other such descriptions in the future.

Finally, the author collected roughly 300 GB worth of audio recordings during the course of the project.
